NOTE:
ŁPāda$ a is reminiscent of, among other famous passages, \BHG\ 11.19:
Łanādimadhyāntam anantavīryam
anantabāhuṃ śaśisūryanetram |
paśyāmi tvāṃ dīptahutāśavaktraṃ
svatejasā viśvam idaṃ tapantam ||$.
See also \BHG\ 10.20cd:
Łaham ādiś ca madhyaṃ ca bhūtānām anta eva ca$ ||.
A faint reference to the \BHG\ seems proper at the beginning of a work that claims to deliver a teaching based on, but also to surpass, the \MBH\ (see following verses of the \VSS). Compare also, e.g., \KURMP\ 1.11.237:
Łrūpaṃ tavāśeṣakalāvihīnam
agocaraṃ nirmalam ekarūpam |
anādimadhyāntam anantam ādyaṃ
namāmi satyaṃ tamasaḥ parastāt$ ||.
To say that a god has no beginning and no end in a temporal or spacial sense is natural (Łanādi°...°antam$), but to have no `middle part' (Ł°madhya°$) in these senses is slightly less so. Thus the rather commonly occuring phrase Łanādimadhyāntam$ is probably a fixed expression usually referring to a deity that is endless, eternal and immaterial. As to which deity or what form of a deity this stanza refers to, it may be Śiva, his name missing in pāda c, but the phrasing of the verse is vague enough to keep the question somewhat open: the impersonal Brahman might be another option, even more so if we look at verses 1.9--10, whose topic is Łbrahmavidyā$.
In Łpāda$ b Łjagat-susāraṃ$ is most probably not to be interpreted as Łjagatsu sāraṃ$ (`the essence in the worlds'). Another way to translate Łavyaktajagatsusāraṃ$ would be: `who is the fine essence of the unmanifest world.'
Strictly speaking, Łpāda$ c is unmetrical, but it is better to simply acknowledge here the phenomenon of `muta cum liquida', namely that syllables followed by consonant clusters such as Łra, bra, hra, kra, śra, śya, śva, sva, dva$ can be treated as short (Łlaghu$). (See Introduction \CHECK) Thus Łharīndrabrahmā°$ can be treated as a regular beginning of an Łupajāti$ (\shortsyllable\ - \shortsyllable\ - -), the syllable Łbra$ not turning the previous syllable long (Łguru$).
The reading Łāsamagraṃ$ in Łpāda$ c is suspect, although the initial Łā-$ might convey some sort of completeness, meaning `all round' (see e.g. KaleHigherGrammar226). The fact that we could percieve the ending of Łpāda$s a and b (Łpāraṃ$--Łsāram$), as well as Łpāda$s c and d, as (in the latter case, oddly) rhyming pairs (Łgraṃ$-Łgraham$) suggests that accepting the reading Łāsamagram$ could be the right decision (as suggested by Alessandro Battistini). I translate this verse accordingly. \msM\ gives an exciting, albeit unmetrical, alternative (Łyat samagraṃ$), but this seems more like a guess to me than the correct reading. For some time I was considering emending Łāsamagraṃ$. The most tempting of all the possible options (Łarcyam/arhyam/arghyam/īḍyam/āḍhyam agraṃ, āsamastaṃ$) seemed to be Łāptam agraṃ$, meaning `appointed/received/respected [by Hari, Indra, Brahmā etc.] as the foremost one'. The fact that the Łakṣara$s Łāsam$ and Łāptam$ look similar in most of the scripts used in our manuscripts could support this conjecture. Łāptam$ could also possibly refer to the text itself, although then the syntax becomes slightly confusing: `I shall recite the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ that was first received by Hari...' etc. Another candidate was Łāḍhyam agram$: `Having bowed to [Him] who contains/is rich with Hari, Indra, Brahmā etc.' I have not emended the text because it is difficult to know if there is any need for change and if there is, which reading to chose. There was no consensus when this verse was discussed in our extended Śivadharma reading group.
Pāda d seems hypermetrical, but it can be interpreted as a Łvaṃśastha$ line, a change from Łtriṣṭubh$ to Łjagatī$ (as suggested by Dominic Goodall).

Vaiśampāyana, a Ṛṣi, disciple of Vyāsa, great-grandson to Arjuna, recited the Mahābhārata at the snake sacrifice of Janamejaya. TRSUBCHAPTER: The names of the cosmic rulers
NOTE: Note that many of the names here and in the following verses are, in the absence of any parallel passage, rather insecure. In order to avoid the repetition of the name Saha, I take the first name here as feminine; Asabhā seems also to be a feminine ruler's name. Later on there seem to come more feminine names (Tejā, Yamunā, Naganā, etc.), therefore it may be correct to interpret some of the names as names of queens. What is clear here is that the list evokes the name Sahasrākṣa, one of the appellations of Indra, the guardian of the eastern direction.

ŁPāda$ a should probably be analysed and interpreted as Łpurāṇam (purāṇānām aśītisahasrāṇi śatāni ślokāni) brahmaṇā kathitam$. NOTE: The syntax of Łpāda$s cd echoes that of 1.73ab above.

Romaharṣa is usually considered to be the same person as Sūta, disciple of Vyāsa Dvaipāyana.
In \BrahmandaPur\ 3.4.67ab (Łmayā caitat{ }punaḥ proktaṃ putrāyāmitabuddhaye$, see note to 1.63 above) Amitabuddhi is clearly the name (or epithet) of Romaharṣa's son. This suggests that the form Łromaharṣāya$ in Łpāda$ a is a mistake for Łromaharṣaś ca$, or similar. MS \msM\ is either transmitting an otherwise syntactically problematic reading (Łromaharṣeṇa$) that is more original than that in most other witnesses, or \msM's scribe is trying to correct the text. Supposing the former, in this case I accepted \msM's reading.
TEXT: daśa dve ca sahasrāṇi purāṇaṃ samprakāśitam|
NOTE: Manuscripts \msCc\ and \msM\ place the Łiti$ of the colophon at the end of the last Łśloka$, before the Łdaṇḍa$s, thus: Łicchasīti$ ||O|| (\msCc) and Łicchasi iti$ ||o|| (\msM). Note also that \msM\ gives the number of Łśloka$s in this chapter, 77, which is almost exactly the number of verses this critical edition has produced. The scribe of \msM\ struggled with eyeskips in this chapter, therefore it seems unlikely that he himself counted the number of verses he had copied and arrived at this very figure. Rather, he copied the number from his exemplar.
